105.  Reforms  to  the  budget  formulation  and  execution  process—through  more  results-
oriented  budget  documents  and  improved  cash  management—would  improve  budget 
allocations and operational efficiency, and reduce corruption. This is likely to be enhanced in the 
medium to longer term, especially after full adoption of the PBB/MTEF approach in the next 5-
year plan. Increases in the 2009 PNPM allocation are expected to have a more immediate effect 
through increased block grant transfers for community-led development projects. The programs’ 
near-term impact on the poor will be realized mostly through the PNPM block grant increases, 
while improved service access and delivery for poorer groups will be realized over the medium 
to longer term. 
 
106.  Resettlement, indigenous people, and environment. Implementation of the DPSP-5 
measures will cause no direct or indirect involuntary resettlement, nor will it lead to any issues 
affecting indigenous peoples. The measures supported under DPSP-5 are unlikely to have any 
adverse environmental impacts. 
B.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
107.  Implementation of DPSP-5 is subject to the following risks: 
 
(i)  External vulnerabilities. Indonesia has weathered the global economic crisis 
well, reflecting its increased resilience to external shocks built up over previous 
years. Factors limiting the potential impacts of external shocks include diversity 
of  exports,  moderate  public  debt,  limited  external  debt  exposure,  and  an 
adequate level of reserves. The banking sector is also now sufficiently strong. 
The  maintenance  of  a  financial  sector  safety  net  supported  by  PESF  and 
DPL/DPSP will further improve the resilience of the banking sector.  
 
Nevertheless, risks remain high, especially during a period of global financial 
turmoil. Indonesia has an open financial system. Domestic residents can switch 
to foreign assets easily and foreign holdings are significant, especially in the 
stock market and government bonds. The country is thus vulnerable to shifts in 
investor  sentiment.  If  significant  funds  are  pulled  back  because  of  liquidity 
demands in other countries and/or increased emerging market risk aversion, this 
could increase pressure on domestic interest and exchange rates. In addition, 
the Government has large gross financing needs over the next few years, and 
tighter credit markets and increased risk aversion could limit the Government’s 
ability to tap international financial markets. This could force the Government to 
cut budgetary outlays to maintain fiscal balance, with adverse consequences for 
infrastructure and social expenditures. It could also distract the Government from 
implementing its medium-term reform agenda, including those supported by the 
DPL/DPSP. 
 
The measures taken since mid-2008 to mitigate the effects of the global financial 
crisis, including the bilateral swap arrangements with the People's Republic of 
China and Japan and support from the PESF, will help reduce this risk. But it will 
also  require  close  cooperation  between  Bank  Indonesia  and  the  economic 
ministries to reassure bondholders that their investments are safe (from inflation 
and exchange rate movements) while drawing in private investment through the 
kinds of structural reforms supported by the DPL/DPSP.

28  
(ii)  Subsidies. As international oil prices have fallen since mid-2008, domestic fuel 
subsides have also declined. The proposed budget for 2010 envisages energy 
subsidies of 1.6% of GDP, down from 1.9% of GDP in 2009 and a recent peak of 
4.5% of GDP in 2008. However, the recent increase in international fuel prices 
suggests that a return to high international fuel prices remains a risk. Fixed 
domestic fuel prices and the subsidies they create represent a threat to fiscal 
sustainability in the longer term. They are also regressive and inefficient, and 
have high opportunity costs. The Government has shown its willingness to raise 
domestic prices and reduce subsidies, most recently in May 2008. ADB will 
continue to engage the Government in this area through policy dialogue.  
 
(iii)  Fiduciary constraints. Utilization of public resources continues to be a concern, 
notwithstanding the improvements underway. The overall fiduciary assessments 
undertaken since the 2001 country financial accountability assessment point to 
considerable  improvements  in  Indonesia's  fiduciary  environment.  Ongoing 
programs supported by several development partners provide significant TA to 
strengthen fiduciary governance. The DPL/DPSP focus on strengthening budget 
preparation,  execution,  and  transparency  in  financial  management  will 
significantly enhance transparency (Appendix 8). 
 
(iv)  Security  risks.  Alerts  stemming  from  sectarian  and  regional  conflicts  and 
terrorism could slow foreign direct investment and set back the tourism industry. 
The  Government  and  law  enforcement  authorities  have  taken  a  range  of 
measures aimed at bolstering public and investor confidence.

DEVELOPMENT POLICY SUPPORT PROGRAM 
A.  Core Policy Area 1: Macroeconomic Stability 
 
1.  The DPL/DPSP series in 2004–2006 sought to improve debt management and fiscal 
policy management by reducing subsidies to the nonpoor and making revenue administration 
more efficient through the expansion of modern tax officers. 
 
2.  Overall  macroeconomic  fundamentals  remain  sound  and  fiscal  consolidation  has 
improved with the expansion of the tax base and improved efficiency of tax administration. From 
2004–2008, economic growth averaged a substantive 5.7%, the public debt-to-gross domestic 
product (GDP) ratio declined nearly 28 percentage points to a moderate 33%, budget deficits 
were manageable, and international reserves remained adequate to provide the country with a 
comfortable liquidity cushion. Increasing non-oil and gas revenues as a percentage of GDP 
were supported by a prior DPL/DPSP action to expand modernization of tax offices and the tax 
base  to  include  medium  and  small  taxpayers.  Additional  reforms  to  improve  tax  analysis, 
including the creation of a Tax Policy Office, are expected to generate improvements in revenue 
collection.  
 
3.  On the expenditure side, reductions in untargeted fuel subsidies in 2005 allowed greater 
social spending, but untargeted subsidies remain burdensome. In 2005, the Government raised 
fuel prices, resulting in the decline of fuel subsidies from 4% of GDP in 2004 to 2.8% in 2006, 
freeing up $10 billion a year. This amount was rolled out into cash transfers targeted at the poor, 
or went toward higher health and education expenditures. However, as oil prices continued to 
break records throughout 2008, fuel subsidies rose sharply, causing the Government to spend 
an  additional  Rp50  trillion  (1.2%  of  GDP)  in  the  first  part  of  the  year.  In  May 2008,  the 
Government again increased fuel prices by almost 30% and accompanied this with a widely 
publicized and improved cash transfer program. This move, together with a reduction in oil 
prices in the second half of 2008, limited the energy subsidy in 2008 to 4.5% of GDP. 
 
4.  Rating  agencies  have  responded  favorably  to  Indonesia’s  lower  debt  ratio  and  the 
reform packages. In a reflection of the country’s more sound economic footing, all three credit 
agencies have raised their credit ratings at least three notches since 2003. Standard and Poor’s 
upgraded Indonesia’s credit rating from CCC+ in 2003 to BB– by 2008; likewise in this period, 
Moody’s raised its ratings from B2 to Ba3; and Fitch raised its from B to BB. In supporting their 
ratings upgrades, the agencies cited debt reduction as the primary cause, as well as the 
Government’s  commitment  to  broad-based  reform,  including  changes  to  investment  laws, 
customs and tax reforms, and fiscal reforms, specifically in treasury and budget—measures 
supported by the DPL/DPSP series. 
 
B.  Core Policy Area 2: Investment Climate 
 
5.  The DPL/DPSP series seeks to improve the investment climate through several key 
entry areas, including regulatory reform, tax reform, custom and trade reform, financial sector 
stability, and improved access to finance by small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). 
 
6.  In 2006, the Government issued three economic policy packages covering investment 
climate, infrastructure, and financial reform. In 2007, a comprehensive follow-up package was 
issued  detailing  168  specific  reform  measures  to  be  carried  out.  As  a  result,  business 
perceptions have improved. A study of manufacturing firms in mid-2007 indicated improvements

in  VAT  refunds,  tax  filing  processes,  informal  payments,  and  faster  import  and  custom 
clearance. Surveys of foreign investors also show that perceptions of Indonesia are improving. 
In the annual Japan Bank of International Cooperation survey, 620 Japanese multinational 
companies, operating in global markets, ranked Indonesia the eighth most promising country for 
overseas business in 2008, similar to its rank in the previous year. Although full implementation 
of  the  investment  policy  packages  has  yet  to  take  place,  initial  signs  are  encouraging—
investment rates have risen from less than 20% of GDP in 2003 to 27.6% in 2008. 
 
7.  Regulatory reforms supported by the DPL/DPSP process, particularly those relating to 
simplifying  and  eliminating  unnecessary  business  licenses  and  multiple  registration 
requirements, have led to more streamlined procedures supportive of the investment climate. 
According to Doing Business 2010, the time to set up a business has fallen significantly from 
168 days in 2003, to 105 days in 2007, to 60 days in 2009.1 Another key achievement has been 
the passage of the Investment Law, which clarified previously arbitrary investment rules. The 
law  focuses  on  equal  treatment  of  foreign  and  domestic  investment,  removes  the  forced 
divestment and limited duration of foreign investment in the old law, lengthens the time horizon 
to hold land, liberalizes some immigration procedures, and allows for international arbitration. 
 
8.  Tax reform has addressed some of the key complaints from the business community. 
Reforms in tax administration have halved the time for VAT refunds; in addition, more than 
Rp10 trillion (roughly $1 billion) in outstanding VAT refunds have been settled. New procedures 
have been put in place to issue VAT refunds to export companies within set time frames. 
Standard operating procedures for a complaint management system have been issued. The 
DPL/DPSP has also supported the issuance of a decree on tax audit procedures that allows 
taxpayers to delay payment of tax assessments from disputed audits. However, this decree only 
affects disputes arising since the 2008 tax year; older disputes continue to be arbitrated under 
the old rule. 
 
9.  Significant progress on trade and customs reform has been made, with pilot testing of 
Indonesia’s national single window (NSW) and paperless import clearance. Implementation of 
the NSW is one of the country’s most important trade facilitation initiatives. Under a single 
window, exporters and importers will no longer be required to apply individually to multiple 
agencies—significantly reducing the number of days it takes to export and import goods. A pilot 
project is underway in Jakarta’s main port and will be expanded to other ports in preparation for 
the establishment of an ASEAN single window. Other trade reforms sought by the DPL aimed to 
improve the technical capacity of the tariff team in setting and evaluating tariff changes and 
nontariff barriers imposed by line ministries. 
 
10.  An original objective of the DPL/DPSP series was to strengthen the financial sector by 
reducing the role of state-owned banks and increasing the share of financial assets at nonbank 
financial institutions. As of June 2008, the share of state-owned banks in the banking system 
(36%) was a significant 10 percentage points less than in 2003, indicating that the role of private 
banks  in  the  sector  is  increasing.  Less  progress  has  been  made  with  nonbank  financial 
institutions—they accounted for 19.9% of total assets in the financial sector as of March 2008, 
compared with a 17.4% share in 2005. However, other indicators point to a healthier financial 
system—profitability ratios such as net interest margin, return on assets, and return on equity 
remain  strong.  Nonperforming  loans,  particularly  in  state-owned  banks,  have  declined 
substantially after peaking in 2005. In terms of diversification, SME lending has been rising 
rapidly and now accounts for half of the lending portfolio.

11.  In strengthening the stability of the financial sector, the DPL/DPSP has supported the 
implementation of a sounder financial safety net. At the start of the DPL series, there was a 
need to reduce the economic distortion and potential moral hazard caused by the blanket 
guarantee that existed at the time, which had been introduced during the Asian crisis 1997–
1998  to  stem  bank  runs.  To  this effect,  the DPL/DPSP  series supported  several  reforms, 
including a deposit insurance scheme, institutionalizing Bank Indonesia’s role as lender of last 
resort, and establishing institutional processes and mechanisms for resolving troubled banks. 
By the end of the DPL-4/DPSP-3 in 2007, coverage on deposits had been reduced from a 
blanket guarantee in 2003 to Rp100 million. Indonesia is one of the few countries in the world 
that removed its blanket guarantee on schedule. In October 2008 the authorities announced 
several confidence-building measures in response to the global financial crisis, including a 
twenty-fold increase in the deposit guarantee to Rp2 billion (approximately $200,000).  
 
C.  Core Policy Area 3: Public Financial Management and Governance 
 
12.  To  improve  the  efficiency,  transparency,  and  accountability  of  public  finances,  the 
DPL/DPSP series has focused on three key areas of reform: (i) modernizing public financial 
management  systems,  (ii)  strengthening  institutional  reform  within  the  Ministry  of  Finance 
(MOF), and more recently (iii) civil service reform.  
 
13.  Changes in the legal and regulatory architecture for PFM are now largely complete and 
the focus has moved toward implementing a modern PFM system. Before the start of the 
DPL/DPSP series, the Government’s financial operations were based on outdated laws (from 
1925) that had been updated with a series of inadequate decrees. The previous PFM system 
allowed for systematic and pervasive corruption, collusion, and nepotism because assignments 
were unclear, transparency was low, and enforcement poor. Budget formulation was opaque 
and inefficient, making it difficult to quantify basic concepts of the budget. Budget execution was 
often delayed and monitoring arrangements were weak. Procurement processes were prone to 
corruption and collusion. Accounting and reporting were fragmented and not always reliable, 
and mandates of government audit bodies were not clearly defined. The DPL supported various 
measures in the areas of budget preparation and execution to create the regulatory framework 
for a more modern PFM system.  
 
14.  A key achievement under the DPL/DPSP series has been the implementation of the TSA 
to improve cash management of public finances. At the start of the DPL series, more than 
18,000 commercial bank accounts—and other accounts not even known to the Treasury—
handled government funds. As an initial step, DPL-1 addressed regulatory deficiencies in the 
PFM  system,  including  the  passage  of  several  laws  defining  the  regulatory  framework. 
Reorganization of MOF was also carried out to begin the process of establishing a TSA, and to 
clean  up  the  Government’s  cash  management  issues.  DPL-2/DPSP-1  then  supported 
regulations underlining these laws and adopted an implementation plan. DPL-3/DPSP-2 pilot 
tested the TSA to have zero-balance accounts in more than 50 provincial treasury offices 
(KPPNs).  DPL-4/DPSP-3  extended  the  TSA  coverage  to  nearly  full  implementation  on 
government  expenditure  accounts.  Progress  on  covering  revenue  accounts  was  more 
complicated, but has now advanced significantly. 
 
15.  Budgeting  procedures  have  improved,  but  execution  remains  problematic.  The 
DPL/DPSP series has helped move forward reforms to reengineer business processes across 
the budget cycle. The national budget is now compatible with the international standard GFS 
classification. Fiscal reporting is more comprehensive and timely. Elements of a medium-term 
expenditure framework have been introduced, although they are not yet fully operational in the

budget system. Whereas the planning and reporting side of the budget process has improved, 
executing the budget has remained weak, with about 50% of capital expenditures being spent in 
the last quarter. 
 
16.  Procurement  reform  has  been  slow  to  take  off.  The  original  trigger  aimed  only  at 
strengthening the existing National Procurement Office. Instead, the Government established a 
new National Public Procurement Agency (LKPP) as an independent office directly responsible 
to the President. As an independent agency with adequate resources, authority, and strong 
political backing, it will be in a stronger position to drive public procurement reform. However, 
because of the time required to set up the LKPP, there was a lack of progress on other 
procurement reforms, such as developing a comprehensive national public sector procurement 
law. This law is needed to address the numerous inconsistencies resulting from decentralization 
reforms, which have enabled authorities at various levels of government to issue their own 
procurement procedures. Other deficiencies of the system include slow progress in the passage 
of  regulations,  and  the  adoption  of  standard  tools  such  as  bidding  documents  and  user 
manuals. 
 
17.  Initial steps to address civil service reform have been launched. Lack of administrative 
capacity  and  distorted  incentives  in  government  bureaucracy  have  constrained both  policy 
implementation and delivery of public services. As an initial step to reforming the civil service, 
the  DPL/DPSP  in  2006-2007  supported  comprehensive  reform  of  the  structure  and 
remuneration framework for high-ranking state officials. A task force was set up to examine the 
entire compensation package with the goal of creating a more transparent, systematic, and 
coherent framework for pay and allowances based on a comprehensive job evaluation and pay 
grading. Building on this, MOF has developed a comprehensive civil service reform plan and 
action plan for itself, which is now being pilot-tested in other agencies.  
 
D.  Core Policy Area 4: Improved Delivery of Public Services 
 
18.  The groundwork for improving poverty targeting of basic services has been initiated. 
Before the rise in fuel prices in 2005, Indonesia’s social protection system was characterized by 
emergency short-term safety net programs and price subsidies. The country’s three targeted 
programs accounted for less than 0.5% of GDP, compared with almost 4.0% of GDP for the 
untargeted fuel subsides, of which less than 0.2% of GDP went to the poorest quintile. As the 
fuel price hike freed up more funds for social spending, the DPL supported capacity building 
initiatives  to  improve  the  targeting  of  these  released  funds.  The  2005  fuel  hike  was 
accompanied by a new cash transfer program to help alleviate the impact on the poorest 
households—representing a substantial shift from the ineffective and inefficient general subsidy 
program. Evaluative assessments were conducted to improve targeting and performance of the 
cash transfer program, and the lessons were incorporated into the new cash transfer program 
that accompanied the May 2008 fuel price increase. The Government has moved to set up a 
comprehensive monitoring and evaluation function, including the establishment of a unit to 
undertake  performance  evaluations,  with  the  findings  to  be  used  as  an  input  to  the 
Government’s planning and budgeting cycle.

FIDUCIARY ASSESSMENT 
A.  Background and Analytical Underpinnings 
 
1.  This note summarizes the current state of the public financial management system, maps 
the reform efforts being conducted, and provides an outlook with regards to overcoming current 
reform challenges, with a view to assessing fiduciary risks.  
 
2.  Public financial management (PFM) reform, as previously outlined in the Government's 
White Paper1, continues to be at the center of attention of Indonesian policy makers, with the 
global  economic  downturn  adding  further  urgency  to  the  agenda:  Indonesia  anticipates  a 
substantial reduction in both tax revenues and foreign exchange reserves resulting from the 
slowdown in the economy and sluggish trade. The exchange rate has weakened since last year, 
driving up the cost of foreign debt servicing, and unemployment is high, which will adversely 
impact the poverty rate.  
 
3.  The crisis has fortunately been tempered by a decline in world oil prices. The decrease in 
oil prices has resulted in a reduction of oil subsidies, providing more fiscal space in the budget to 
counter the effects of the global economic downturn. Also, as a result of ongoing efforts among 
key stakeholders, well-sustained reforms have mitigated the impact of this downturn on the 
country’s  economy.  Nonetheless,  PFM  systems  in  the  country  now  face  unprecedented 
challenges to ensure efficient and effective budget allocations and disbursements, in line with the 
policy responses to the global and domestic economic turmoil.  
 
4.  In the face of these challenges, the commitment of key stakeholders in the budget 
process to vigorously pursuing the reform agenda remains unwavering and strong. The evolving 
agenda continues to be broad-based, comprising (i) improving results orientation in state budget 
planning and development, (ii) improving budget and treasury management, (iii) strengthening 
monitoring  and  evaluation  of  public  expenditures  and  programs,  (iv)  improving  public 
procurement systems, and (v) improving the Government accounting and audit functions. In 
summary, the agenda is designed to improve how revenues are raised and how funds are 
allocated, used, and accounted for—both at the central and regional levels. PFM improvement 
continues to be a key area of focus for DPL-6/DPSP-5, which will be a crucial instrument for the 
Government to flexibly, and in a self-determined fashion, underpin and flank its reform targets.  
 
5.  The following assessment draws on recent economic and sector work undertaken by 
Asian Development Bank (ADB), the World Bank, and other development partners. A public 
expenditure and financial accountability assessment was concluded in June 2008. In addition, 
this assessment has taken into account the findings of a joint World Bank–IMF mission on 
strengthening budget management undertaken in June 2008, the results of a previous joint 
World Bank—IMF mission on budget reform priorities reported to the Government in June 2007, 
the September 2008 update of the Report on Observance of Standards and Codes on Fiscal 
Transparency in Indonesia from 2006,2 and an ADB sector report on accountability and audit in 
Indonesia.3 The assessment also draws on the ongoing policy dialogue and advisory services

the timeliness, reliability, and transparency of budget disbursement and reporting as well as 
improve the capability of managers in the efficient management of public resources. Business 
process improvements in the area of budget formulation and budget execution are underway and 
are expected to be completed by 2011. A SPAN turnkey implementation vendor has already 
been contracted (the contract was signed on 10 July 2009).

management and weak procurement capacity in the implementing agencies, especially at the 
provincial and district levels.

6.  Reforming Regional Public Financial Management 
 
47.  Decentralization has provided subnational governments with significant resources and 
responsibilities.  More  than  one-third  of  public  spending  is  now  executed  by  subnational 
governments. This level of expenditure requires an adequate regulatory framework, together with 
sufficient PFM capacity, at the subnational level if it is to be fully effective. To address this need, 
in  2005  the  central  Government  passed  comprehensive  legislation  on  PFM  reform  at  the 
subnational level, with the aim of mirroring reforms already being implemented at the national 
level. However, most regions lack the technical and human resource capacity to implement the 
reforms. For example, subnational governments are obliged by law to report certain fiscal and 
financial  information  to  the  central  Government  within  a  clear  time  frame.  In  reality,  many 
subnational governments struggle to meet their deadlines for submission. 
 
48.  Current budget allocation and disbursement practices contribute to fiscal discipline at the 
central level but constrain successful financial management at the local level. Allocations to 
individual  subnational  governments  are  formally  issued  after  the  passage  of  the  central 
Government  budget  in  October  for  the  following  year,  and  commence  through  derivative 
regulations  (e.g.,  ministerial  decrees).  While  this  may  appear  to  allow  sufficient  time  for 
subnational governments to finalize their budgets, in reality budget allocations of shared, non-tax 
revenue (oil and gas) are frequently issued in the first few months of the fiscal year. The 
allocations are frequently underestimated by the central Government and disbursements from 
the center to the regions are back-loaded toward the end of the fiscal year. This is because the 
transfers  in  the  final  quarter  are  based  on  actual  revenues,  which are  usually  higher  than 
projected revenues. 
 
49.  Subnational governments are struggling to spend their increased budgets and have built 
up  reserves  in  recent  years  for  three  main  reasons.  First,  they  often  underestimate  their 
revenues because they lack revenue management capacity. This is compounded by the Central 
Government’s under-budgeting of transfers. Second, delays in the budget approval process and 
lack of implementation capacity result in under-spending of budgeted programs by subnational 
governments. Third, subnational governments may not have the capacity to spend the resources 
at their disposal when these resources increase significantly and abruptly. This was the case 
with the 64% increase in "general allocation funds" from 2005 to 2006, which led to a significant 
increase in subnational government reserves. 
 
50.  Some challenges in addressing PFM constraints at the subnational level include: (i) 
providing timely estimates from the sectoral ministries of revenue-sharing transfers; (ii) building 
the capacity of subnational governments to manage accumulated reserves; and (iii) improving 
and streamlining the budget approval process. The need to streamline the budget approval 
process  in  particular  affects  Law  No.  33/2004,  which  stipulates  that  provincial  and  district 
budgets must be approved by the Ministry of Home Affairs and the provincial government. This 
process may be one factor that lengthens the budget approval process. 
 
51.  To address the financial management issues and challenges at the subnational level, the 
central Government has implemented several reforms: 
 
52.  “Burden-sharing policy.” Introduced in 2009, this policy incorporates major subsidies, 
including fuel subsidies, into the "general allocation funds". The policy will increase the accuracy 
of transfer projections during the full fiscal year, given that there is a disincentive for the central 
Government  to  underestimate  the  oil  price  assumption,  especially  in  relation  to  regional

which in turn will help subnational governments better plan their budgets.  
 
53.  Two actions are needed to optimize this policy. First, the central Government should

subnational government by postponing the transfer of its "general allocation funds" (25% of 
monthly transfers) until the budget is submitted. This initiative has resulted in more timely budget 
submissions. Between 2006 and 2007, 54% of subnational governments approved their budgets 
after March. In 2008, the year the sanction was introduced, 87% of subnational governments 
submitted their budgets to MOF before March.

clear  these  arrears  by  drawing  on  reserves;  and  (ii)  where  subnational  governments  have 
constant or increasingly high levels of reserves, using them to increase investment in public 
infrastructure.

Before the Asian financial crisis, Indonesia had been successful in fighting poverty. The poverty rate—the proportion of

remarkable, close to half of the population still lives below the $2/day international poverty line (2008). Disparities 
across regions are striking, as provinces in outlying regions have poverty rates that are well above the national 
average.  
 
 
The Medium-Term Development Plan (RPJM) for 2005–2009 focuses on poverty reduction and the achievement of the 
Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). Its priority areas include (i) job creation and poverty reduction programs; 
(ii) macroeconomic stability with stable prices, fiscal sustainability, and financial sector reforms; (iii) accelerating 
investments, exports, and tourism through reforms for a healthy business climate and flexible markets; (iv) improved 
access to and quality of education and health; and (v) infrastructure development by improving the efficiency in 
delivering existing services and by greater private sector participation.

Infrastructure investments in poor rural areas will improve access to social services and accelerate social development. 
 
Better targeting of PNPM support to improve basic infrastructure in poor villages will contribute to addressing the major 
causes of poverty as identified in the National Poverty Reduction Strategy paper, including (i) lack of access to key 
social services, (iii) poor infrastructure in villages, and (iv) inadequate links to markets. Indonesia’s infrastructure 
provision in poor rural areas is weak by regional standards. Electrification rates are the lowest in the region, while road 
networks are limited and in poor condition. People living in isolated areas with poor market links lack both economic 
opportunities and adequate levels of service delivery. More than 15% of all Indonesian villages are inaccessible all year 
round. Lack of access to quality education significantly decreases productivity, employment opportunities, and personal 
income. Investments in transportation infrastructure, agricultural infrastructure (irrigation), and education and health 
facilities can significantly improve living conditions in remote areas, create the basis for economic growth, and improve 
the welfare of the local population. The positive effect of infrastructure investments on rural welfare has been 
empirically demonstrated; surveys have revealed that there’s a significant correlation between the presence of good 
roads and a community’s mean level of income.a  
 
Approximately 60% of the population lives in rural areas where agriculture is the main source of livelihood. One reason 
for low incomes in the agriculture sector is that “farm gate prices” are very low compared with urban prices for the 
same goods of the same quality. This is due to high transport costs for rural marketable surpluses over poor quality 
roads. Transport costs are even higher for non-motor-vehicle transport methods in areas where roads are absent. In a 
rapid assessment of causes of poverty in five of Indonesia’s districts, villagers in isolated areas identified high transport 
costs as a major cause of poverty. New roads in previously unserved agricultural areas can significantly lower 
transaction costs and hence raise farm gate prices, which will mean higher incomes for people in the agriculture sector, 
the poorest group of the population.  
 
B.  Consultation and Participation 
  
During  preparation,  regular  consultations  were  held  with  key  stakeholders  (government  officials,  NGOs  and 
development partners). During implementation, the program will maintain broad stakeholder participation to discuss 
and  review  reform  efforts.  The  Government’s  National  Community  Empowerment  Program  (PNPM)  supports 
community empowerment and strengthens local capacity and governance to implement infrastructure investments. 
The Government has engaged extensively with civil society on tax and investment law reforms. The entire set of 
DPSP-5 policy actions will likely feature in discussions with Parliament.

C. Gender and Development 
1. Key Issues.  
 
The  country  gender  assessment  identified  four  key  themes  through  a  consultative  process:  (i)  the  impact  of 
decentralization on gender, (ii) women’s inadequate representation in political decision\ making, (iii) violence against 
women, and (iv) women and international migration. While Indonesia has made progress over the years, gender 
inequalities persist. Indonesia was ranked 111 out of 182 economies in the United Nation's human development index 
in 2007 and 93 out of 155 in the gender development index. In 2007, women’s labor force participation was 40%, 
compared with 80% for men. The shift to regional autonomy under the decentralization law has already shown potential

for increased participation of women in local governance.  
 
2.  Key Actions.  
 
Drawing a comprehensive conclusion on issues related to gender and income poverty in Indonesia is difficult, as 
consistent, disaggregated data by sex is not available. DPSP-5 will create indirect gender impacts. Improved poverty 
targeting of public spending will increase women’s access to essential services for achieving MDG targets, including 
reducing child and maternal mortality. Improvement of financial management systems and governance, through 
increased transparency and accountability at all levels, will provide civil society with the basic information necessary to 
monitor government actions and empower men and women in communities to participate in policy and budget 
decisions. To the extent that policies under DPSP increase credit to micro, small, and medium enterprises, the program 
would have an indirect beneficial impact on women considering their predominant role in microenterprises. 
 
The community-driven development approach used by the Government's PNPM program will ensure that perspectives of 
both men and women are represented in planning, designing, and implementing village infrastructure investments. The 
community implementation organizations’ executive committees will include at least two women, and at least 40% of the 
total membership will be women. Experience from the PNPM Mandiri reveal that the number of women on the committees 
varies from few women to entirely women, depending on the circumstances of individual villages.
